blocks.text: FIRST DAY - Saturday, August 3, 1957. From Lancaster, Pa. via Pennsylvania and New Jersey Turnpikes to New York City; Merritt Parkway in Connecticut to New Haven; Route #1 along shore of Long Island Sound; to Charlestown, R. I., for night; 7:00 A. M. to 8:00 P. M. 355 miles.

(Right) On schedule...the baggage is lined up on the curb ready to be placed in the trunk of the car. The there are undoubtedly many people who take careful measurements of each piece of baggage, and then measure the trunk, to be sure everything will fit. We, blithely, take as little as we feel we will need, cast an eye on the size of the trunk, and hope everything will go inside. Happy result: all the suitcases and paraphernalia shown here fit perfectly, with no room to spare. It's not much fun to go on a long trip and wrestle with an assortment of suitcases inside the car. This is especially true when there are six making the trip. We're off to a good start.
The one stop between Lancaster and New York for a bite to eat on the Penna. Turnpike.
Best bargain of the entire trip, the ferry ride from Staten Island to Manhattan (82¢).

In Manhattan, we take the Express Highway north along the Hudson River to the George Washington Bridge, cut across city to gain the Merritt Parkway, which we follow to New Haven, Conn. A hot day, traffic is very heavy, a number of cars must be pushed off the hwy. when they overheat and stall from the constant stop-and-go.
Aboard the ferry, excellent view of New York's skyline. Off to the left is the Statue of Liberty. This is Nancy and Kathy's first visit to New York.

blocks.text: In New Haven we inspect the grounds and buildings of Yale University...then along the coast of Long Island Sound, a section noted for the charm of its Colonial villages, to Guilford, Conn., one of the best preserved of all these historic towns.
The First Congregationalist Church.
Many of the stately old homes bear the date of construction and name of the original owner. (Strain your eyes; is this Strain's? Is this the dlate owner. (Strain ydour eyees; iiiiis thils 1792??)
The cihhildrenren wanted to know what a salt box house is...so so we show them it good example, built in 1761.

blocks.text:
Not the best accommodations the first night,
but "No Vacancy" signs are going up, and we decide to take what is available.
The "Rhode Island Redd" welcomes us to Rhode Island...first visit to the state by all the children.
After dark we drive a few miles to Charlottestown Beach for a swim in the Ocean.

blocks.text: SECOND DAY — Sunday, August 4, 1957. Charlestown, R. I. across Narragansett Bay to Newport; northeast to Plymouth, Mass.; to Boston; to Gloucester; across narrow neck of New Hampshire; into Maine at Kittery. 6:50 A. M. to 8:50 P. M. 266 miles — total 621 miles.
Off the main road, to Point Judith, where Narragansett Bay and the Atlantic Ocean meet, for a look at the lighthouse and the sea wall. A gray sky promises rain.
Across Jamestown Bridge (90¢) to Conanicut (pronounce like Connecticut) Island in Narragansett Bay. We are early and wait 45 minutes for the ferry to Newport to take on coal.
Craft of the U. S. Navy in the Bay as we approach Newport by ferry ($2.25). Rain fails to discourage the activities of the children.

blocks.text: Newport, R. I. is both an historic old town and the site of some of the most famous homes in America built about the turn of the century. The city was founded in 1639 by religious dissenters from the Massachusetts Colony. Before the Civil War it was a resort for Southern planters; then came the Boston influx; finally New York society took over to vie with one another in creating almost unbelievably elaborate palaces. Came the depression and high taxes...the glory days are over.

It's hard to convince the children this is a private home.
This is a ppprrrivavayatette thee hhhmmmmmm...
The Ocean Drivrrive, where many of the homes are located, is largely spoiled by a heavy rainfall.

For $6.60 we tour "The Breakers", the Vanderbilt mansion which was erected at a cost of $3-$6 million. Gordon manages to get an available light picture of the music room before being politely informed picture taking is forbidden.

blocks.text: Across country to Plymouth, celebrated as the site of the first permanent English settlement on our American shores...founded by the Pilgrims who landed from the "Mayflower" on December 21, 1620. Today, there is some industry and fishing, but the town appears to be primarily a tourist attraction.
A gaily painted sign welcomes us to Plymouth.
National Monument to the Forefathers rises 8l feet above hill, said to be largest granite monument in world.
A d doubtfullly authentific P moulth Rock i covered by a marble colonade.

blocks.text:
We speed through Boston, formerly a traffic bottle-neck with its narrow streets, on a new throughway,
and under the Charles River via the Summer Tunnel,
so that the children barely get an impression of
the city. The new throughway is a remarkable engi-
neering feat, but we'll have to return again some
day to see the city.

From the North Shore Shooonere,
Kathy points to the sky line of Boston (not visible on picture).
skkshkylhiine offil Bostconcong (Bostconcong vivivisiiisiiiblle on piccted on pictttcrrre).
One of the brightly lighted Drive-Ins north of Boston. We have hamburgers, cokes and sundae's.

Gloucester, Mass., is one of the great fishing ports of the Atlantic coast. For several hundred years her ships have visited the treacherous Grand Banks, on which 10,000 of her fishermen have lost their lives.
The monument, known to every school child, is dedicated to the children that go down to the sea in ships.

The harbor is crowded with fishing boats of every description.
Lookrent which many consider the best boat in the fleet, and has been fitted out for a trip to Florida.
From Gloucester, we visit Rockport, which many artists claim as their home...then encounter a severe rain storm as we circle Cape Ann.

York Beach, Maine, in the early morning. Kathy appears to have gotten herself marooned.

Good time is maintained through Brunswick, Bath, Wiscasset, Bath, Wiscasset, Damariscotta...to Penobscot Bay.

blocks.text: In Rockland,Rockland, Maine, time out for a lobster dinner in this center of the lobster region.
This graceful suspension bridge over the Penobscot River at the head of Penobscot Bay.

In the distance, across the bay, are the mountains of Mt. Desert Island which contains Bar Harbor and most of Acadia National Park, some of the finest scenery of the whole Maine coast. On this trip it is necessary to skip this side trip, which all of us have made several times before, since we must be in St. John in the morning for the boat trip to Digby.

In Rockland,Rockland, Maine, time out for a lobster dinner in this center of the lobster region.

This graceful suspension bridge over the Penobscot River at the head of Penobscot Bay.

In the distance, across the bay, are the mountains of Mt. Desert Island which contains Bar Harbor and most of Acadia National Park, some of the finest scenery of the whole Maine coast. On this trip it is necessary to skip this side trip, which all of us have made several times before, since we must be in St. John in the morning for the boat trip to Digby.

blocks.text: At the very tip of the peninsula to the east of Mt. Desert Island is Schoodic Point, a not too well known part of Acadia National Park. Here the Ocean waters slam into rocky troughs with a great swishing sound, followed by high sprays. The sea gulls are so tame they almost can be fed by hand. There is a fine rockbound coast along this peninsula.

blocks.text: All is well....the boat does not sail for two hours...the girls fall asleep in the lounge after the short rest of the previous night.

Sleep vanishes when word makes the rounds the army is coming aboard. And what an army!...almost 400 men from a Black Watch regiment, all attired in kilts. The girls make a dash for the rail to see them embark.
A bagpipe concert en route (fine, if you like bagpipe music).

blocks.text: After a trip of 46 miles across the Bay of Fundy, which requires about three hours, we are piped ashore at Digby, all of us setting foot in Nova Scotia for the first time. A slow tire leak delays us for almost an hour.
Cost of trip across Bay of Fundy on the "Princess Helene" - $28.30.

Nova Scotia, meaning New Scotland, is one of the Maritime Provinces of Canada. It is composed of a peninsula and an island. The first white settlers were French who called it Acadia. Later the English acquired the region and many of the Acadians were forced from their homes, an incident made famous by Long-fellow's "Evangeline". There were also settlements by Swiss and Germans. About one fourth of the population is of Scottish descent. The period of greatest settlement came at the close of the Revolutionary War when about 35,000 Loyalists came from the United States. The descendants of each of these different peoples have retained their characteristics, language and customs to a remarkable degree.

Heading southwest along the North Shore from Digby. The air is pure and bracing - it's good to be alive. Most of the inhabitants are fishermen, our road along the coast being the only inhabited section; the interior remains a forested wilderness.

blocks.text: The tides of the Bay of Fundy are known to be the highest in the world. These boats will be floated when the tide comes in.
In this first day's drive along the North Shore we see the only oxen of the trip, although they are supposed to be fairly common in this section.
Cole Harbour
Engineers at work. The children get a chance to stretch and exercise their muscles when we make an early stop for the day.
Kitty in the booth of a lunch room which adjoins our cabin.

blocks.text: FIFTH DAY — Wednesday, August 7, 1957. From West Pubnico continue along shore of Nova Scotia to Halifax, with side trips to "The Ovens" and Peggys Cove; night at Dartmouth. 10:00 A. M. to 10:00 P. M. 306 miles — total 1,488 miles.
A late start this fifth day, for the children sleep eleven hours to make up for the lack of sleep the night before.
Lobstertter traps near Clarks Harbour on Cape Sable Island, the most southerly part of Nova Scotia.
Cindy examines a shore made yellow by the presence of millions of barnacles.

Along this extreme southwestern part of Nova Scotia we find the roads strewn with what appears to be sea weed, out in the sun to dry. We discover it is Irish moss, which after drying is bagged and sold. Of its use, we failed to get any details.

This is typical of the road along southwest Nova Scotia - not interesting, mostly thru cut-over woodland, rarely a house to be seen, except when the road makes contact with some of the villages along the shore. These coastal villages were generally founded by Loyalists from New England at the close of the Revolutionary War. Their number ran to 35,000, including half the then living graduates of Harvard.
Louisiuee with a handful of ooff Canadian currency. An unfavorable exchange rate makes Gordon pay $12 for the exchange of $200. United States money.

blocks.text: The section of the coast near Lunenburg known as "The Ovens", where the waters of the Atlantic have worn caverns into the sides of the rocky cliffs. Here about the middle of the last century there developed a gold rush, of which only a few traces remain today.

High above the Atlantic, we watched the waters beat against the rocky shore.
Against Kitty's vehement protests, the girls enter a cave to see the waves dash inside with an eerie sound.

blocks.text: This night at Margaree at a private home is an interesting experience. For supper we have fresh fried haddock and homemade bread; breakfast is a large affair of eggs and cereals. The owners who are most friendly vacate two of their bedrooms for our use. Cost for our six, supper, rooms and breakfast is $20.

SEVENTH DAY — Friday, August 9, 1957. Margaree north to Cabot Trail; south along east shore to Sydney; along Bras d'Or Lake to (near) St. Peters. 7:00 A. M. to 6:00 P. M. 278 miles — total 2,057 miles.
(Left) A "Welcome" to Cheticamp, center of the hooked rug making section of Cape Breton. The day is bright and clear. At 6:00 A. M., the temperature was in the low 40s.
More Gaelic is spoken today in Cape Breton than in the ancestral country.
At infrequent times we leave the coast, and these valley scenes are typical; but at no time is anyone more than a few miles from water on Cape Breton.

On the Cabot Trail, we enter Cape Breton Highlands National Park, which is located in the northern part of Cape Breton Island. Here is the most spectacular of the mountain-and-sea scenery which is perhaps without parallel on the North American Continent.

This night at Margaree at a private home is an interesting experience. For supper we have fresh fried haddock and homemade bread; breakfast is a large affair of eggs and cereals. The owners who are most friendly vacate two of their bedrooms for our use. Cost for our six, supper, rooms and breakfast is $20.

SEVENTH DAY — Friday, August 9, 1957. Margaree north to Cabot Trail; south along east shore to Sydney; along Bras d'Or Lake to (near) St. Peters. 7:00 A. M. to 6:00 P. M. 278 miles — total 2,057 miles.

(Left) A "Welcome" to Cheticamp, center of the hooked rug making section of Cape Breton. The day is bright and clear. At 6:00 A. M., the temperature was in the low 40s.

More Gaelic is spoken today in Cape Breton than in the ancestral country.

At infrequent times we leave the coast, and these valley scenes are typical; but at no time is anyone more than a few miles from water on Cape Breton.

On the Cabot Trail, we enter Cape Breton Highlands National Park, which is located in the northern part of Cape Breton Island. Here is the most spectacular of the mountain-and-sea scenery which is perhaps without parallel on the North American Continent.

blocks.text:
(Left) This picture, enlarged from a 35mm negative,
shows the Cabot Trail as it winds up and down along
the Cape Breton highlands facing the Gulf of St.
Lawrence.
(Right) On top of the mountains at almost 1,500 feet the trees, buffeted by winds from every direction, have a scrawny look of defeat.

The Trail begins the descent on the eastern side of the Island, with Aspy Bay in the distance. Here in June, 1497 John and Sebastian Cabot are believed to have landed and claimed the new world for the king of England.

blocks.text: At Cape North village we decide to drive to the northern extremity of Cape Breton Island, chiefly for the satisfaction of having been there. Leaving the Cabot Trail we follow a dirt road between Aspy Bay and Sugar Loaf Mountain; then cut across a gap in the Moun-tain to the small fishing community called Bay St. Lawrence. This is as far as we can go - the land has run out, the ocean takes over. This side trip is about eleven miles each way.

A sure spot to get away from it all; this farm is for sale.
A surrree spsoot to gett oeway fromit all; thiiis t farm is for sae.
farmfarrm foor sall e.
A new school and two of the pupils in the shadow of Sugar Loaf Mountain.
Approaching the fishing village of Bay St. Lawrence. Few tourists get here.

blocks.text: These boattws with the bow 
This is as far as we can go - we have reached the end of land. We have reacquainted the end of land.
After spending a half hour here enjoying the humidity-free air, we retrace our route to Cape North Village and the Cabot Trail.

blocks.text: Exclusive (and expensive) Keltic Lodge sits high on a narrow peninsula between North and South Ingonish Bay.
Kittycatly climbs out on a rock to watch the capers of the children.

The mountains are passed, the road is rough and so dusty an oncoming car can be seen a half mile away just by the cloud of dust it raises. The road improves as we near Sydney through a coal and iron region. In Sydney, situated on one of the finest harbors in America, we mail cards and letters to friends at home.
A brief wait at Ross Ferry on our way to Sydney.

blocks.text: EIGHTH DAY — Saturday, August 10, 1957. St. Peters on Cape Breton Island return to mainland of Nova Scotia; again through Antigonish; westward to Pictou and Amherst; enter New Brunswick to Moncton; to (near) Shediac, N. B. for night.

Back on the mainland, this lonely lobster but is typical of many along the Bay of St. Lawrence.
This itty bitty piccalic of ma mnnnyy alalongong the BAY of St.. Lawrenccncee...
MAGNETIC HILL TO APPRECIATE THIS PHENOMENON PROCEED TO SPOT INDICATED BY WHITE POST TURN OFF MOTOR RELEASE BRAKES

Just over the New Brunswick line, near New Dorchester, this long covered bridge. We are back in the section influenced by the tides of the Bay of Fundy. At high tide, the water rises almost to the floor of the bridge.

blocks.text: The whole atmosphere seems to change as soon as we begin to drive along the Gaspe road. Perhaps it is the roads side signs in both English and French, perhaps the quaint villages with the abundance of children among the road, peaceful in late afternoon. The Baie des Chaleurs appears more of us feel a new exhilaration, a sense of expectancy.

The children go for a swim and play badminton. For supper we drive into the village of Maria where the children have their first experience trying to order a meal from a waitress who speaks or understands no English. The menu is printed in French on opposite sides, so we merely point. Most of the orders come through correctly.

blocks.text: TENTH DAY — Monday, August 12, 1957. Maria along south shore of Gaspe Peninsula; to Perce; to Gaspe; to Cape Gaspe lighthouse; to Cap des Rosiers on eastern tip of Gaspe Peninsula for night. For right: 7:05 A. M. to 6:10 P. M. .
From the Dalhousie ferry, around the Gaspe Peninsula, to Quebec is a distance of about 700 miles, almost all of it within sight of water. All but about 50 miles is now paved.
ST.CHARLES DE CAPLAN BUREAU POSTE POST OFFICE
Under a bright sky, we continue our trip along the Baie des Chaleurs.
This is a common sight: for generations the people of the Gaspe have dried their cod on "flakes".

Every one who makes this tour remembers the dog-drawn carts. The children wait along the road for the approach of a car, coax the dog to a standing position, and hope the tourist will stop to take a picture, which is usually good for about 25¢.

In 1534 Cartier visited these shores,
entered Gaspe Bay and took possession
of the land for the king of France.
This was the beginning of France's
claim to a share of the New World.
See trip to the Gaspe
Peninsula in 1938 with
Bob and Myrtle Zecher.

then across a rise of land, and behold!... the culmination of the entire trip - Perce Rock comes into view.

blocks.text:
(Right) The panorama of Gaspe: the village,
the Rock and Bonaventure Island offshore.
(Enlarged from a 35mm negative.)
Perce Rock, the pierced rock, unique in all the world, is 1,420 feet long, and including the obelisk 1,555 feet, 300 feet wide at its widest point, and 288 feet high.
Fishing boats ply the waters of the harbor, the "put-put" of their engines so constant you soon become unaware of the sound.

The landscape changes: the relatively flat roadbed on the south shore gives way to a winding mountain road which impartially rides high for short stretches, then levels out along the shore.

Gaspe Bay, which Cartier first visited in the year 1534.

blocks.text: An off-the-beaten-path side trip of nine miles along the shore of Gaspe Bay brings us to Cape Gaspe lighthouse. The road winds and dips, and the last climb to the lighthouse is as steep as any road we have even encountered. All the children complain of car-sickness. But the view from the lighthouse set on the very edge of the cliffs is well worth the extra mileage expended. The sun is setting over the Bay as we return along the narrow road.

blocks.text: From the top of the cliffs at Cape Gaspe lighthouse it's 700 feet straight down to the waters of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. In the far distance, perhaps fifteen miles away, across the mouth of Gaspe Bay, can be seen the faint out-lines of Bonaventure Island, Perce Rock and the mountains to the west. This is one of the finest vistas along the eastern coast of North America.

blocks.text: Along the south shore of the St. Lawrence River, a section of fertile farmlands. The fields are long and narrow, unlike the square fields at home, and extend to the water's edge. Most of the barns have off-center doors like the one above.
A stop for the night at this cottage ( $10) near the town of Trois Pistoles. From the porch we watch the sun set over the St. Lawrence River.

TWELFTH DAY — Wednesday, August 14, 1957. Trois Pistoles; along St. Lawrence River to Levis; cross River to Quebec; along north shore to Ste-Anne-de-Beaupré. 10:25 A. M. to 5:10 P. M. 188 miles — total 3,284 miles.

blocks.text: In Riviere du Loup we have our second disappointment of the trip. We had planned to take the ferry across the river to St. Simeon, and then head into the Laundrette Mountains before reaching the ferry dock but we reach the ferry going to Quebec is pulling out, rather just as the ferry is pulling out, than wait at least four hours for another boat so decide to continue along the south shore

blocks.text: Village of Ste. Anne de Beaupré has many quaint old buildings, numerous eating places and street side shops where religious novel-ties can be purchased. Tourists get a big play.
World famous Basilica of Ste. Anne de Beaupré, visited by several hundreds of thousands of thousandsof pilgrims annually.
Dozens of motels.

Dozens of motels have sprung up in the neigh-borhood of Ste. Anne's. This is the only spot on the whole trip we find competition among motel keepers. Result: a new, modern motel for only $8. Who says competition does not help the customer?

blocks.text: THIRTEENTH DAY - Thursday, August 15, 1957. Ste-Anne-de-Beaupré return to Quebec for better part of day; recross St. Lawrence River (bridge); south on R#5 to Sherbrooke. 8:30 A. M. to 6:40 P. M. 181 miles - total 3,465 miles.
(Left) The long suspension bridge from the north shore to the Isle d'Orleans, not far from Quebec.

Returning to Quebec, we take the old road which winds through a farm country little changed in two hundred years. The outside stairways to the second floor must be a French characteristic, also frequently seen in the older sections of Quebec city.

The site of Quebec, capital city of the Province, was first viewed by Cartier in 1535, although the city itself was founded by Champlain in 1608. Every school child knows the story of the conquest of Quebec by the English General Wolfe in 1759 during the French and Indian War. Although today Quebec and all Canada are a part of the British Empire, Quebec city remains largely French in influence, ninety per cent of the inhabitants speaking French, and ninety-seven percent are Catholic.
First thing in Quebec, a carriage ride for about two hours ($5.50, including the tip).
One of the city gates. Quebec is the only walled city in America.

blocks.text: Castle-like Chateau Frontenac and Dufferin Terrace offer commanding views of the lower city and the traffic on the St. Lawrence River. In the far distance is the Isle d'Orleans and the Laurentian Mountains.
Champlain's statue stands at the lower end of Dufferin Terrace. Founder of the city in 1608, his exploits took him to the Great Lakes and the Mississippi River.

Waiting for Gordon to take them shopping,
the girls later decide there are no bar-
gains in Quebec.

blocks.text:
Said to be Quebec's oldest house.
Quebec's Quebeec's ceec's old oldeeeestt old house.
Never has a dwelling been so squeezed by its neighbors.
One of the more modest hostelryries, the Hotel Chateau Normandie, the Place d'Armes.

Sous-le-Cap, narrowest street in North America, the lower town. When we are forced to stop after failing to make a short turn into the street, we are set upon by half dozen of the dirtiest urchins imaginable. They climb into and over the car making grabs for anything they can get their hands on. Nothing of value is lost. Gordon is determined, over Kitty's pro-tests to go through...so, with the windows closed and locked, we push through like conquering heroes. No one bothers to get out of the way, so we manage to scrape the front fender in our passage.
Old houses, narrow streets, tiny squares are a part of the Quebec scene...and its charm.

blocks.text: Scenes in the lower town by Gordon while Kitty and the children take the elevator to Dufferin Terrace. The little French girl consents to having her picture taken in exchange for a peach.
Just outside the city, heading for home, the Quebec Bridge, whose center cantilever is the longest and heaviest in the world.
Food where you can find it.

Night at a cottage near Sherbrooke ($10) after a new motel owner has asked us $18). This shop (left) will cash customers' American travellers checks without charging the 6% exchange...so Cindy and Kathy emerge with a lambskin rug for their room at home.

blocks.text: FOURTEENTH DAY - Friday, August 16, 1957. Sherbrooke, Quebec, south to reenter the United States at Norton, Vt; east into New Hampshire and south to tour a section of the White Mountains; again into Vermont to St. Johnsbury; west to South Cambridge, Vt., foot of Mt. Mansfield. 8:30 A. M. to 7:00 P. M. 259 miles - total 3,724 miles.

Unlike most trips we are ahead of schedule,
due to our missing visits to Prince Edward Island and the Laurentian Mountains. It is decided to make a circuit of the White Mountains of New Hampshire, which we have not seen for several years.

This covered bridge in Canada just before returning to the United States. We cross the bridge to get a better picture, only to discover a sign stating the bridge has been condemned. We try to shake it as little as possible on the return to the main road.
The U. S. Custom's Office. About four ques-tions asked, no examination of baggage, and we're back in the United states again. All of us say it's good to be home.

Luxurious Balsams Hotel, Dixville Notch.
We are disappointed in Dixville Notch,
finding it far less spectacular than we
had been led to believe.

captions: FOURTEENTH DAY - Friday, August 16, 1957. Sherbrooke, Quebec, south to reenter the United States at Norton, Vt; east into New Hampshire and south to tour a section of the White Mountains; again into Vermont to St. Johnsbury; west to South Cambridge, Vt., foot of Mt. Mansfield. 8:30 A. M. to 7:00 P. M. 259 miles - total 3,724 miles.

Unlike most trips we are ahead of schedule,
due to our missing visits to Prince Edward Island and the Laurentian Mountains. It is decided to make a circuit of the White Mountains of New Hampshire, which we have not seen for several years.

This covered bridge in Canada just before returning to the United States. We cross the bridge to get a better picture, only to discover a sign stating the bridge has been condemned. We try to shake it as little as possible on the return to the main road.
The U. S. Custom's Office. About four ques-tions asked, no examination of baggage, and we're back in the United states again. All of us say it's good to be home.

Luxurious Balsams Hotel, Dixville Notch.
We are disappointed in Dixville Notch,
finding it far less spectacular than we
had been led to believe.

blocks.text: Crawford Notch, location of the landslides in 1826, where, as told by Hawthorne, the inhabitants of a farm house rushed from their dwelling on hearing the avalanche only to be crushed to death, while the farm house remained untouched.
Looking back onto Crawford Notch. Nearby is the Mt. Washington Hotel and the cogwheel railroad to the summit of Mt. Washington.
Something new in covered bridges ...this one for a railroad. (No, we can't tell why the bridge does not catch on fire from the sparks from the engines.)
Dam across the Connecticut River where we re-enter Vermont from New Hampshire.

blocks.text: Across northern Vermont, considerably out of our direct way home for the sight, is Mount Mansfield, highest point in the state, 4393'. Our intention - to cross through Smugglers Notch.
One of the most pleasant overnight spots of the trip, this double-roomed cottage almost at the foot of Mt. Mansfield ($8).
It is early in the evening, so we take a hike on a country road and partake of bucolic things...such as a friendly dog and a cow that continues to "moo" for several hours.

blocks.text: FIFTEENTH DAY — Saturday, August 17, 1957. South Cambridge, Vt. through Smugglers Notch to Stowe; to Waterbury; south through central Vermont on R#100 to Plymouth and Weston; west into New York State to Saratoga Springs; to Schenectady.

SMUGGLERS' NOTCH
Forbidden Trade with Canada passed through here. 1808-14.
The Notch gained its name after Jefferson's Embargo Acts of 1808 and the War of 1812, when cattle were driven north and Canadian goods were smuggled into New England through this picturesque gap beside majestic Mt. Mansfield remote from revenue officers.
Early in the morning, through Smugglers Notch, famous since Colonial days and especially since the early part of the last century when smugglers used this pass to exchange goods with Canada.

blocks.text:
Plymouth, a hamlet in the very heart of Vermont,
is the birthplace of Calvin Coolidge, thirtieth president of the United States. The place is the more impressive because the true rural simplicity of the spot has been maintained.
A mile away is the cemetery where he is buried along-side his son who died while he was president. The simple headstone does not even state he was president of the United States.

blocks.text: In south-central Vermont is Weston now the center of the Vermont Guild of Old Time Crafts and Industries. Here are products of wood, clay, silver and iron, paintings and antiques, glassware and clothing. We purchase several articles as mementoes.

The New York state line. Our intentions are good...to enter New York well north of the highly populated sections and thus avoid heavy traffic, but in Saratoga Springs we encounter a racetrack crowd which delays us for more than an hour. Finally, we locate a motel south of Schenectady for the night.
A final covered bridge in Vermont as we cut westward for New York state.

blocks.text: SIXTEENTH DAY — Sunday, August 18, 1957. Schenectady, N. Y., southwest on R#7 to (near) Binghamton; south into Pennsylvania to Scranton; new section of Penna. Turnpike to (near) Allentown; to Reading; and home.
Gordon in front of motel near Schenectady waits for Kitty and the girls to get ready, one of the inconveniences of having six people in two rooms with only one bath.
Nancy displays the sweater she purchased in Weston, Vt. the day before.
It's noon...we are back again in Pennsylvania after having driven 128 miles this day in New York.
